Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) \\) governed by \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a real constant. We analyze the effect of a transformation defined by \\( g(z) = e^{\\alpha t}z \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant, over time t.

If \\( g(z) \\) is applied to the initial value \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve following \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\) without further intervention, will the state \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(z) \\) changes the initial value to \\( e^{\\alpha 0} z_0 = z_0 \\), so initially it is the same, but as t progresses, the factor \\( e^{\\alpha t} \\) significantly modifies the trajectory of \\( z(t) \\), so that \\( z(t) = e^{(i\\omega + \\alpha)t} z_0 \\), not merely \\( e^{i\\omega t} z_0 \\) as it would be otherwise.
